newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: APEC told energy key to Asia-Pacific future growth.
newsitem.headline: APEC told energy key to Asia-Pacific future growth.

text.p: Energy will be the key to the Asia-Pacific region's economic growth into the next century, Australian Energy Minister Warwick Parer told the inaugural APEC energy ministers' meeting on Wednesday.
Parer said the Asia-Pacific's ability to meet growing energy demand to fuel a forecast 3.3 percent annual growth rate would determine whether the region was the driver of global growth beyond 2000.
"Energy in its various manifestations is central to this," said Parer in opening the two-day Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) meeting.
But the region would need US$1.6 trillion in capital investment to meet energy demands over the next 10 years, he added. "Involvement of the business sector will be vital."

An industry consultant warned that the Asia-Pacific, which consumes about half the world's energy, was unlikely to meet its growing energy demands because political and economic risks could impact on foreign investment in new energy projects.

APEC expects energy consumption among its 18 members to grow by around 2.2 percent a year to 2010, compared with only 1.0 percent a year for the area represented by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD).
"I don't think there's any way these demand forecasts can be met," Robert Moeller, energy specialist for management firm Booz-Allen & Hamilton, told Reuters.
"If you look at a country like China, they have to build the equivalent of one new large central power station a month," said Moeller, adding demand in India was nearly as high as China.
However, he said both countries had significant problems that outweighed some of the smaller countries grouped under APEC, whose leaders meet for a summit in the Philippines in November.

APEC groups Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, and the United States.
Delays faced by U.S. firm Enron Corp over gaining clearance for a major power plant in India until recently stunned would-be developers of power projects in India, Moeller said.
There was also the problem of a lack of a comprehensive regulatory or legal framework in some countries that most western firms were familiar with, he said.
"As a result it ends up being quite scary when you think about a billion or multi-billion-dollar investment," he said.

When the risks of large-scale investments in the larger countries were weighed "it brings those markets down far enough to make places like Thailand and Indonesia and Malaysia also look quite attractive", Moeller said.
Australia's Parer issued an optimistic note in opening the APEC meeting, saying energy was a fertile ground for co-operation between Asia Pacific nations.
APEC ministers will review a 14-point plan aimed at making investment regimes for energy more attractive.
"Visionary policies to respond to these energy challenges will be required," he said.
